buildup.text: Karl Popper argued that good science makes bold predictions that could be proven wrong.

discovery.text: Falsifiability is the key: a theory that can't be tested can't be scientific.

twist.text: Theories survive not by being proven true, but by surviving every attempt to prove them false.

climax.text: This is why science changes. When evidence contradicts a theory, the theory must adapt or die.

punchline.text: Science isn't about certainty. It's about the best explanation so far.

quiz.question: What makes a theory scientific according to Popper?
options: It must be falsifiable â€” capable of being proven wrong
It must be proven absolutely true
It must be accepted by all scientists
